subject: Fashion
title: Planned Obsolescence in Clothing
description: A quick, practical guide to Planned Obsolescence in Clothing.

hook.text: Your grandmother's coat lasted decades. Your jacket from last winter is already pilling.

buildup.text: In the 1950s, clothes were built to endure. Double-stitched seams, heavyweight fabrics, real buttons.

discovery.text: Today, brands use thinner fabric, weaker thread, and cheaper dyes so garments degrade faster.

twist.text: It's not bad luck. It's strategy. If your clothes lasted, you'd stop buying new ones.

climax.text: Planned obsolescence, once a trick for light bulbs and phones, now drives the fashion industry.

punchline.text: Your clothes aren't failing. They were designed to.

quiz.question: What is planned obsolescence in the fashion industry?
options: Designing clothes to wear out quickly so consumers buy replacements sooner
A government regulation limiting how long brands can sell a single design
A trend cycle where designers intentionally revive old styles
